As an Indian citizen, you have several rights under the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, if you are subjected to sexual harassment by a colleague in your workplace. Specifically, you have the right to:

* Report the incident to your employer or HR department within three days of the alleged incident
* Request an inquiry into the allegations without fear of retaliation
* Receive a decision on the complaint within 90 days of filing the complaint
* Be protected from any form of sexual harassment or intimidation during the inquiry process

Additionally, your employer has a legal obligation to:

* Take immediate action to prevent further sexual harassment
* Provide you with adequate support and protection
* Conduct an inquiry into the allegations and take appropriate disciplinary action against the perpetrator

It is important to note that under this Act, any form of unwelcome behavior or comment of a sexual nature, including but not limited to, physical contact, gestures, comments, or threats, can be considered sexual harassment.

If you experience sexual harassment in your workplace, do not hesitate to seek help and support. Your employer has a legal obligation to protect you from such conduct, and you have the right to report it and receive a fair and timely resolution.

data.question: What are my rights as a citizen to ensure that any difficulties arising from the implementation of the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013 are addressed and resolved by the Central Government?
data.ground_truth:
As a citizen, your rights are to ensure that any difficulties arising from the implementation of the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013 are addressed and resolved by the Central Government. You have the right to lodge complaints or grievances related to sexual harassment at workplace with the authorities. Under this Act, every employer is required to set up an Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) to investigate and resolve complaints of sexual harassment. You can approach your employer's ICC or the External Complaints Committee (ECC) at the district level if you face any difficulties in resolving your complaint through the internal mechanism. The Central Government has also established a National Compliance Committee to oversee the implementation of this Act and provide necessary guidance to employers and employees.

You have the right to seek assistance from the ECC or the ICC if you face any harassment, intimidation, or retaliation while pursuing your complaint. The ECC can also provide psychological counseling and support services to survivors of sexual harassment.

In case of any difficulty in resolving your complaint through the ICC or ECC, you can approach the Central Government's National Compliance Committee for further assistance. Your employer is also responsible for ensuring that your complaint is investigated thoroughly and resolved fairly, taking into account all relevant evidence and testimonies.

As a citizen, it is essential to remain informed about your rights and responsibilities under this Act. You should familiarize yourself with the procedures and mechanisms established by your employer and the ECC or ICC, and seek assistance if you face any difficulties in resolving your complaint.

As per the Act, any provisions made by a government agency should be laid in the Official Gazette within two years from the commencement of the Act. In summary, the government agency can make provisions to remove difficulties in implementing the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act within two years from its commencement, and any such provisions should be laid in the Official Gazette.
